comments.body:
It's before `WithPanicRecovery` - this is so we can access the audit ID from the context when we log error message inside the `WithPanicRecovery`  handler. 
If `WithAuditID` panics, `net/http2` will catch it and then log the panic with stack trace.
sounds fine

	handler = genericapifilters.WithAuditID(handler)
	return handler
}

comments.body: so we do a nil check everywhere else within this file, but I think it was accidentally missed here; in actual execution, if the feature gate is enabled, `c.FlowControl` will never be nil. However, in this unit test, we don't set the feature gate, and `c.FlowControl` never gets set either, so the following Install call fails. Thankfully a pretty harmless nil pointer dereference :sweat_smile:
This and the fuzzer test were the only two that failed and I locally verified them. The other two CI failures (bazel and e2e-gce) seem to intermittent failures. Hopefully all green this time :D
Great, thanks for the quick fix!
move behind WithWaitGroup, like in the insecure case.

comments.body: As an administrator, I'd like to know my apiserver's current id by e.g. visiting some page on apiserver. Can I do that? What do you think about adding a standalone metric, e.g. where apiserver-id is a label? I'm totally open to other ideas too.

Good point. I was relying on the hostname+pid to provide the debug info. 

Having it in a metric makes sense. A similar case is the `/version` endpoint, which also has a metric "kubernetes_build_info" mapped in `/metrics`. We can start with a standalone metric. 

What do you think of having this in a followup PR? I think it can be a Beta graduate criteria, if the name / format gets controversial.
Sure, a followup sounds fine.
:+1: â€“ a little more verbose here, but nicely contained where we define the chain.

Yeah, either way would be OK with me.

comments.body:
just to double check, from the KEP:

> For incoming requests, this would go below WithRequestInfo in the filter stack, as it must be after authentication and authorization, before the panic filter, and is closest in function to the WithRequestInfo filter.

above/below are a little ambiguous... this constructs the filters "inside out"... the last filter added here runs first. Is the intent to run this filter **before** almost all other filters, including authn/authz and request received timestamp (not "after authentication and authorization" as described in the KEP)?

I'm having trouble remembering the original conversation, but here is the comment I left: https://github.com/kubernetes/enhancements/pull/1458#discussion_r426961816.  The WithRequestInfo reference may not be as relevant anymore since it was recently moved in #102934.  I think the intention is that it is executed _after_ authentication, so I've placed it to be executed after (above in code) the authentication filter.
no need for the comment IMO.

What is a post start hook?

Missing trailing dot.

> What is a post start hook?
> 
> Missing trailing dot.

Same as the existing poststarthook you can specify on the server.  This is a way to avoid side-effect code like I removed where a config is create, but the config doesn't work unless a poststarthook is later added in a separate step.

Updated the comment so we know its the same as the existing poststarthook.

it's designed i think. here we applies a `option-->config-->completed-config-->new` flow and it's commonly used in kubernetes world

Right.  We did not put something in options, so the story starts with config for our feature.  I followed the standard pattern after config in #80956.

I realized my first comment here is wrong.  I was thinking of reading config objects while constructing the handler chain, but have since realized that this does not make sense.  We have to initialize the filter's data structure to a useful default (as outlined in the KEP) and let the regular config object handling update that.

comments.body: clever

Kudos to @jpbetz, who looked into a production cluster, the biggest json:proto ratio for a single object is ~2.3. So 10 is a very generous estimation.

FWIW, I also did some maths in mind:
* large primitive type Kubernetes have is int64, size ratio for int64 is log(2^64-1)/log10/2 = 9.1
* for field names, the longest field that is wrapped in a list is `terminationMessagePolicy`, which is 24 chars long. It will be 1 byte in proto. ([bash one-liner](https://pastebin.com/AqRyprHi)).
doesn't this require updating the expected value in tests? same for the other change
and if authn or authz is nil? We panic?

it won't panic. authn/authz will just be bypassed

[https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/529785e35564d52b08b3ce303df5faf4055d6d31/staging/src/k8s.io/apiserver/pkg/endpoints/filters/authorization.go#L46-L49](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/529785e35564d52b08b3ce303df5faf4055d6d31/staging/src/k8s.io/apiserver/pkg/endpoints/filters/authorization.go#L46-L49)

[https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/529785e35564d52b08b3ce303df5faf4055d6d31/staging/src/k8s.io/apiserver/pkg/endpoints/filters/authentication.go#L54-L57](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/529785e35564d52b08b3ce303df5faf4055d6d31/staging/src/k8s.io/apiserver/pkg/endpoints/filters/authentication.go#L54-L57)
But here we check the `Authn/zInfo` structs, not the actual authenticators/authorizers. These info pointers can be nil. Then this code here panics.
ðŸ‘ðŸ»updated

We are returning here now if either of the two is nil. I.e. we disable bearer token authz if authn is not plumbed the normal way through. I don't think this is an too important code path. But for complete and correctness we might want to skip line 593 or 596 respectively.

/cc @liggitt
previously we required both to be nil? what is the behavior with only authn or only authz configured?

> what is the behavior with only authn or only authz configured?

- __authn enabled && authz disabled__: this is useful for AA servers. w/ authz disabled, the server will disable delegated (subject review) authorizer (for our case, we place the request validation into one compiled-in admission controller since it's less costy). and w/ authn enabled, the user's info will still be passed as admission attributes so that the admission could work.
- __authn disabled && authz enabled__: it doesnt seem to work. iiuc, authn should be a prerequisites to authz?
